page.title: 18Woodlands surrounding Kenn
page.content: The area around Kenn and Kennford is covered with many types of trees. In the main the land used for farming has trees in clumps, mainly of the deciduous type, such as oak, beech and chestnut. There are still the remains of elm trees to be found, trees that died in the late 1970's after being attached by the Dutch Elm Beetle. Some farmers have planted new trees in their place, which at the moment are very young and immature trees. The trees in their clumps in and around the fields give protection to farm animals during inclekent weather. The trees on the Haldon escarpment tend to be coniferous type, mainly Scots Pine. The woodlands of Haldon come under the care and protection of the Forestry Commission. This timber is used either for building or papermaking. Small animals and deer abound in the woods.
